comments.title: Typical Water Pressure
comments.body: Reasonable water pressure was observed. A typical drop in flow was experienced when two or more fixtures were operated at the same time.

ai.notes: Use when overall pressure is acceptable and only normal drop is noted with multiple fixtures.

comments.title: Main Shutoff Valves Not Operated
comments.body: Since main shutoff valves are operated infrequently, they can become stiff, leak, or break when operated after a long period of inactivity. For this reason, main shutoff valves were not operated during the inspection. Caution is advised when operating older shutoff valves.

ai.notes: Use as a standard limitation whenever main shutoff valves are not operated.

comments.title: Supply Piping Leak
comments.body: A leak was observed in the supply piping at (location). Repair or replacement by a qualified plumber is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when active leakage from pressurized water lines is present.

comments.title: Corrosion on Supply Piping
comments.body: Corrosion was observed on the exterior of the supply piping at (location). This area should be monitored and repaired if leakage develops.

ai.notes: Use when rust or mineral build-up is visible but no active leakage is confirmed.

comments.title: Old Steel Supply Piping
comments.body: Old steel water supply piping was observed. This material is prone to interior corrosion and constriction of the pipe diameter over time, which can reduce water pressure. Replacement is typically performed when loss of pressure becomes unacceptable.

ai.notes: Use when galvanized/steel supply lines are present.

comments.title: Polybutylene Supply Piping
comments.body: Polybutylene water supply piping was observed. This gray plastic pipe has a history of premature failure in some installations. Leaks and deterioration have been reported. Further evaluation by a qualified plumber and ongoing monitoring are recommended.

ai.notes: Use when gray polybutylene piping is present. Do not state it is failing unless leaks are observed.

comments.title: Supply Piping Freeze Risk
comments.body: Supply piping serving the outbuilding may be susceptible to freezing during very cold weather. Insulation or heat tracing may be desirable.

ai.notes: Use when exposed supply piping is outside conditioned space.

comments.title: Supply Piping Poorly Supported
comments.body: The supply piping lacks adequate support at (location). Better support or strapping is recommended to reduce movement and stress on fittings.

ai.notes: Use when piping is hanging, sagging, or loosely supported.

comments.title: Supply Valve Handle Missing
comments.body: A supply valve handle is missing at (location). Repair or replacement is recommended to allow proper operation.

ai.notes: Use when valve is present but cannot be operated normally.

comments.title: Supply Valve Handle Damaged
comments.body: A supply valve handle is damaged at (location). Repair or replacement is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when the handle is cracked, bent, or not securely attached.

comments.title: Water Hammer
comments.body: Water hammer (banging or rattling of pipes) was observed when operating plumbing fixtures. Over time this can stress pipe connections. Pipe support improvements and/or water hammer arrestors may be desirable.

ai.notes: Use when noticeable banging is heard when fixtures are shut off.

comments.title: Supply Piping Workmanship
comments.body: The installation of the supply piping at (location) is not workmanlike. While no active leakage was observed today, this may increase the likelihood of future problems.

ai.notes: Use when connections appear sloppy or non-standard but intact.

comments.title: Cold Water Condensation
comments.body: Condensation was noted on portions of the cold water piping. If this becomes a concern, insulation could be added to reduce condensation.

ai.notes: Use when droplets form on cold pipes in humid areas.

comments.title: Cross Connection
comments.body: A potential cross connection was observed between the potable water supply and a source of contamination at (location). This condition should be corrected by a qualified plumber.

ai.notes: Use when a hose or fixture could allow backflow into the potable supply.

comments.title: Old Well Pressure Tank
comments.body: The well pressure tank appears old. As with any older mechanical component, it is difficult to predict remaining life. Replacement may eventually be needed.

ai.notes: Use on well systems when tank appears aged.

comments.title: Add Local Shutoffs
comments.body: Additional shutoff valves at (location) would be beneficial to allow easier isolation of plumbing fixtures for future maintenance.

ai.notes: Use when fixtures lack local shutoff valves.

comments.title: Dissimilar Metal Connection
comments.body: Dissimilar metals were observed in the supply piping connection at (location). This can lead to galvanic corrosion and leakage. Installation of proper dielectric fittings by a qualified plumber is recommended.

ai.notes: Use where copper connects directly to steel/galvanized without dielectric union.

comments.title: Possible Waste Line Obstruction
comments.body: The waste piping at (location) may be obstructed or draining slowly. Further evaluation and any needed cleaning or repairs by a qualified plumber are recommended.

ai.notes: Use when drains back up, gurgle, or drain very slowly.

comments.title: Trap Leaking
comments.body: The trap is leaking at (location). Repair or replacement is recommended to prevent water damage.

ai.notes: Use when active drip or water staining is present at a trap.

comments.title: Flexible Trap Not Recommended
comments.body: A flexible waste pipe or trap has been installed at (location). These fittings are prone to clogs and leakage. Replacement with properly sized rigid piping is recommended when practical.

ai.notes: Use when corrugated or flexible traps are installed.

comments.title: Trap in Suspect Condition
comments.body: The trap at (location) appears to be in suspect condition. This area should be monitored, and repairs made if leakage or odors develop.

ai.notes: Use when trap is rusted, patched, or poorly assembled but not leaking.

comments.title: S Trap
comments.body: An "S" trap was observed at (location). S traps are prone to siphoning and can allow sewer gases to enter the home. Replacement with a properly vented P-trap is recommended during future plumbing upgrades. Fixtures should be monitored for sewer odors.

ai.notes: Use when S-shaped traps are visible under fixtures.

comments.title: Insufficient Waste Pipe Slope
comments.body: Portions of the waste piping do not appear to have adequate slope for proper drainage. Corrective work by a qualified plumber is recommended to help prevent blockages.

ai.notes: Use when horizontal drains appear flat or back-pitched.

comments.title: Waste Piping Poorly Supported
comments.body: Waste piping at (location) lacks adequate support. Improved support or strapping is recommended to prevent sagging and joint stress.

ai.notes: Use when piping sags or hangs loosely.

comments.title: ABS Waste Piping
comments.body: ABS plastic waste piping was noted. In some installations, this material has been prone to problems at the joints, especially where exposed to temperature extremes. Connections should be monitored for signs of leakage.

ai.notes: Use when ABS is present, particularly in attics or exterior walls.

comments.title: Waste Connection Suspect
comments.body: A waste piping connection at (location) appears suspect or non-standard. This area should be monitored and repaired if leakage occurs.

ai.notes: Use when odd fittings or patch repairs are present but not leaking.

comments.title: Old Waste Piping
comments.body: Much of the waste piping is older material. Older piping can be more prone to problems and may require repair or replacement on an as-needed basis.

ai.notes: Use for cast iron, clay, or older mixed piping.

comments.title: Lead Waste Piping
comments.body: Lead waste piping was observed. This material is old and prone to leakage at joints. Replacement may eventually be needed.

ai.notes: Use when lead bends or other lead components are visible.

comments.title: Main Drain Cleanout Not Found
comments.body: No cleanout for the main drain was found during the inspection. It may be prudent to locate an existing cleanout or have one installed to allow easier maintenance.

ai.notes: Use when main cleanout cannot be located.

comments.title: Sewer Odor Detected
comments.body: A sewer odor was detected at (location) during the inspection. This area should be monitored. If unpleasant odors persist, evaluation and repair by a qualified plumber is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when noticeable odor is present in a localized area.

comments.title: Waste Venting Suspect
comments.body: The presence of adequate venting for the waste piping at (location) is suspect. Gurgling or slow drainage may indicate venting issues.

ai.notes: Use when fixture performance suggests venting problems.

comments.title: Roof Vent Height
comments.body: A plumbing vent stack at (location) terminates too close to the roof surface. Vent stacks should generally extend several inches above the roof. Correction is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when vent terminations are unusually short or undersized.

comments.title: Waste Piping Concealed
comments.body: Portions of the waste and vent piping are concealed by finishes, insulation, or soil and could not be inspected.

ai.notes: Use as a standard limitation where appropriate.

comments.title: Sink Drain Stop Missing or Sticks
comments.body: The sink drain stop at (location) is missing or does not operate properly. Adjustment or replacement may be desirable.

ai.notes: Use when pop-up or stopper does not seal or is absent.

comments.title: Tub Drain Stop Missing or Sticks
comments.body: The tub drain stop at (location) is missing or not working properly. Adjustment or replacement may be desirable.

ai.notes: Use when tub stopper will not hold water or is missing.

comments.title: Toilet Loose
comments.body: The toilet at (location) is loose at the floor. Loose toilets should be removed, the connection and surrounding floor checked for leakage, and the toilet properly reinstalled with a new wax ring.

ai.notes: Use when the toilet rocks or moves under light pressure.

comments.title: Toilet Runs On
comments.body: The toilet at (location) continues to run after flushing. Adjustment or replacement of tank components is recommended to reduce water waste.

ai.notes: Use when tank does not shut off reliably.

comments.title: Shower Diverter Not Working
comments.body: The tub spout diverter at (location) is not functioning properly. Water continues to flow from the spout while the shower is in use. Repair is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when diverter does not adequately send water to shower head.

comments.title: Tile Shower Requires Repair
comments.body: The tiled shower stall at (location) requires repair. Loose or damaged tile, grout, and caulk should be repaired or replaced as needed. Any damaged wall structure behind the tile should also be repaired if present.

ai.notes: Use when cracked grout, loose tile, or water damage is evident.

comments.title: Tub Rust – Interior
comments.body: Rust was observed inside the bathtub at (location). While no leakage was observed at the time of inspection, this suggests some deterioration and the tub should be monitored.

ai.notes: Use when enamel is chipped and rust spots are visible.

comments.title: Tub Rust – Underside
comments.body: Rusting was observed on the underside of the bathtub at (location). No leakage was observed today, but leakage could occur as deterioration progresses. Monitoring and eventual repair or replacement may be needed.

ai.notes: Use when underside is accessible and rust is visible.

comments.title: Tub and Shower Caulking Maintenance
comments.body: Water intrusion from tubs and showers is a common cause of concealed damage. Periodic re-caulking of seams, corners, tub lips, tub spouts, and faucet trim plates is an important ongoing maintenance task.

ai.notes: Use as a general maintenance note for baths and showers.

comments.title: Whirlpool Tub Testing
comments.body: The whirlpool tub at (location) was filled above the jets and operated to check basic function. Pump and supply piping are typically concealed and were not fully visible for inspection.

ai.notes: Use when a whirlpool tub is present and you performed a basic operational test.

comments.title: Whirlpool Tub Debris
comments.body: Debris was ejected from the whirlpool tub jets during testing. Professional cleaning of the circulation system is recommended before use.

ai.notes: Use when dark debris or buildup appears during operation.

comments.title: Hose Bib Isolating Valve
comments.body: An interior isolating valve for the exterior hose bib at (location) was not found. Installing a shutoff valve can make winterization easier and help protect from freezing.

ai.notes: Use when no interior shutoff is present in cold climates.

comments.title: Hose Bib Leaking
comments.body: The hose bib at (location) is leaking. Repair or replacement is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when dripping is observed at the handle or spout.

comments.title: Hose Bib Loose
comments.body: The exterior hose bib at (location) is loose and should be properly secured to the wall.

ai.notes: Use when the faucet moves relative to the wall.

comments.title: Hose Bib Damaged
comments.body: The hose bib and/or handle at (location) is damaged. Repair or replacement is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when handle is broken or body is cracked.

comments.title: Hose Bibs Operational
comments.body: Exterior hose bibs were tested and operated normally at the time of inspection unless otherwise noted.

ai.notes: Use as a positive operational note.

comments.title: Hose Bibs Not Tested – Cold Weather
comments.body: Exterior hose bibs were not tested due to low outdoor temperatures and the risk of freezing.

ai.notes: Use when shut off or not tested due to weather.

comments.title: Water Heater Operational
comments.body: The water heater was operating and no obvious leakage was observed at the time of inspection.

ai.notes: Use when unit works and appears dry.

comments.title: Hot Water Temperature High
comments.body: The hot water temperature at the fixtures measured approximately (temperature)°F, which is higher than generally recommended and can create a scald hazard. Reducing the water heater temperature to about 120°F is recommended for improved safety.

ai.notes: Use when measured temperature exceeds ~120°F.

comments.title: Old Water Heater
comments.body: The water heater appears to be near or beyond the typical service life. While it was operating today, replacement should be anticipated.

ai.notes: Use when age suggests limited remaining life.

comments.title: Water Heater Prior Leakage
comments.body: Staining or corrosion suggests prior leakage at the water heater. No active leakage was observed today, but the unit should be monitored closely.

ai.notes: Use when rust or staining is present around seams or base.

comments.title: Water Heater Leaking
comments.body: The water heater is leaking. Repair or replacement by a qualified plumber is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when active leakage is visible from tank or fittings.

comments.title: Water Heater Service Recommended
comments.body: Servicing of the water heater by a qualified professional is recommended to help ensure safe, reliable operation.

ai.notes: Use when unit appears older or burner is dirty, even if operating.

comments.title: Water Heater Burner Dirty
comments.body: The water heater burner assembly appears dirty or sooted. Cleaning and adjustment are recommended.

ai.notes: Use when visual inspection shows soot or debris.

comments.title: Corrosion at Water Heater Connections
comments.body: Corrosion was noted where the water heater connects to the supply piping. This is a common condition but should be monitored for leakage.

ai.notes: Use when rust is present at nipples or unions.

comments.title: Hot/Cold Reversed at Water Heater
comments.body: The hot and cold connections appear to be reversed at the water heater. Correct connection is recommended for best performance.

ai.notes: Use when labeling or piping indicates hot/cold reversal at the tank.

comments.title: No Cold Supply Shutoff
comments.body: No cold water shutoff valve was observed at the water heater. Adding a shutoff valve would make future service easier.

ai.notes: Use when cold inlet lacks a local shutoff.

comments.title: TPR Discharge Pipe Missing
comments.body: The temperature and pressure relief (TPR) valve on the water heater lacks a proper discharge pipe. For safety, a pipe should be installed and terminated near the floor.

ai.notes: Use when valve has open outlet.

comments.title: TPR Valve or Pipe Leaking
comments.body: The TPR valve or its discharge piping shows signs of leakage. Evaluation and repair or replacement by a qualified plumber is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when crusting, staining, or active drip is present at outlet.

comments.title: Improper TPR Discharge Pipe
comments.body: The discharge piping for the TPR valve is not configured as typically recommended. It should terminate in a visible location, generally not more than about 6 inches above the floor. Correction is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when pipe is capped, reduced, or ends too high.

comments.title: Water Heater Wiring Unprotected
comments.body: Wiring serving the electric water heater is not adequately protected. Conduit or appropriate cable protection is recommended.

ai.notes: Use when NM cable enters without strain relief or conduit is missing where typically expected.

comments.title: Burner Compartment Cover Missing
comments.body: The burner compartment cover is missing from the water heater. Replacement is recommended for safety and proper combustion.

ai.notes: Use when combustion chamber is open.

comments.title: Water Heater Backdrafting or Spillage
comments.body: The water heater venting system shows evidence of backdrafting or exhaust spillage. This is a potential safety hazard and should be evaluated and corrected by a qualified HVAC technician or plumber.

ai.notes: Use when draft test or staining suggests flue gases are not drafting properly.

comments.title: Copper Used for Gas Piping
comments.body: Copper piping appears to have been used for gas distribution at (location). This is not generally recommended in this area. Correction by a qualified plumber or gas contractor is advised.

ai.notes: Use when copper is clearly used for gas lines and local practice discourages it.

comments.title: CSST Gas Piping Bonded
comments.body: CSST (corrugated stainless steel tubing) gas piping was observed and appears to be bonded as recommended.

ai.notes: Use when bonding clamp and conductor are visible.

comments.title: Sump Basin Sealed for Radon
comments.body: The sump basin lid is sealed as part of the radon mitigation system and could not be opened for inspection or testing of the pump.

ai.notes: Use when sealed covers prevent normal testing.

comments.title: Radon System Operating
comments.body: The radon mitigation system appeared to be operating at the time of inspection, as evidenced by the in-line fan and pressure indicator.

ai.notes: Use when manometer or fan indicates operation.

comments.title: Concealed Plumbing Not Inspected
comments.body: Portions of the plumbing system are concealed by finishes, insulation, or soil and could not be inspected. Only visible, accessible plumbing components were evaluated.

ai.notes: Use in the plumbing limitations section of the report.

comments.title: Plumbing Performance Not Fully Determined
comments.body: The inspection does not determine exact flow rates, volume, pressure, temperature, or long-term adequacy of the plumbing system. Fixtures were tested using normal operating controls where accessible.

ai.notes: Standard boilerplate for plumbing scope of inspection.

comments.title: Certain Plumbing Components Excluded
comments.body: The inspection does not include water conditioning equipment, solar water heaters, fire or lawn sprinkler systems, or private waste disposal systems unless specifically contracted for.

ai.notes: Use as global plumbing limitation.

comments.title: Tub and Shower Overflow Not Tested
comments.body: Tubs and showers are not tested with the weight of a person standing in the fixture, and overflows are not intentionally tested. Leaks may occur under different use conditions.

ai.notes: Use as a standard limitation for bathroom fixtures.
